reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s “value as product of factors / eutopia is fragile” move, arguing that assuming (near-)independence overstates how rare mostly-great futures are because institutional quality, deliberation norms, and epistemics would induce positive correlation across many dimensions. This is a meaningful supporting pillar for the ‘narrow target’ intuition, but it’s not the whole case: the paper also argues for fussiness via population ethics, digital minds, bounded/unbounded value-function structure, fat-tailed value-efficiency, and moral-uncertainty normalization. So even if independence were undermined, a substantial part of the overall conclusion could remain. On strength, the point is conceptually sound (correlation matters; negative correlation suggests tradeoff/frontier modeling), but it remains schematic: it doesn’t show that correlations are strong enough to materially thicken the upper tail, nor that the relevant dimensions are governed by a single latent “institutional quality” variable rather than partly orthogonal philosophical uncertainties (e.g., population ethics) that good governance might not resolve. Relevance is high because Forethought explicitly leans on multiplicative/product-of-factors reasoning across the Better Futures work (a Tier-2 style modeling assumption) and is plausibly interested in whether the ‘narrow target’ result is an artifact of independence assumptions. Overall, it’s a useful partial challenge but not close to a refutation of the paper’s main conclusion.
title: "Multiplicative fragility model relies on independence assumption"
